page.title: 09Places of interest
page.content: {The Crowstone} The Crowstone is a large demarcation stone that stands out in the mud opposite the bottom of Chalkwell Avenue. It was put there to show the limits of the authority of the Port of London. There is another similar stone opposite in Kent. Both stones are in the Thames. This authority finished in 1709. Now all the waters are under the authority of the City of London and local councils rent the water. The Crowstone which stands there now is the second one. The first on stands in Priory Park outside the museum. Written by Sarah Wall (10yrs)
